Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Motto \Mot"to\, n.; pl. {Mottoes}. [It. motto a word, a saying, L. muttum a mutter, a grunt, cf. muttire, mutire, to mutter, mumble; prob. of imitative origin. Cf. {Mot} a word.] 1. (Her.) A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldic achievment. [1913 Webster]
2. A sentence, phrase, or word, prefixed to an essay, discourse, chapter, canto, or the like, suggestive of its subject matter; a short, suggestive expression of a guiding principle; a maxim. [1913 Webster]
It was the motto of a bishop eminent for his piety and good works, . . . ``Serve God, and be cheerful.'' --Addison. [1913 Webster]
motto n : a favorite saying of a sect or political group [syn: {slogan}, {catchword}, {shibboleth}] [also: {mottoes} (pl)]
